events.title: Birth
events.summary: Johann Pachelbel was born in Nuremberg into a middle-class family, son of Johann Pachelbel, a wine dealer, and his second wife Anna Maria Mair. He was baptized on 1 September, though the exact date of his birth is unknown.
events.fun_version: Johann Pachelbel, a musical wizard born to a middle-class family in Nuremberg, popped into this world! His dad, also named Johann, was a wine dealer, which gives a whole new meaning to family business! His mom, Anna Maria Mair, had to keep a watchful eye on all that merriment. He was baptized on September 1st, but they never figured out the exact date when this musical genius arrived!

events.title: Early Education
events.summary: Pachelbel received musical training from Heinrich Schwemmer and later became a student at the University of Altdorf, where he was appointed organist of St. Lorenz Church. He left the university due to financial difficulties and completed his studies at the Gymnasium Poeticum in Regensburg.
events.fun_version: Pachelbel received musical training from Heinrich Schwemmer and later became a student at the University of Altdorf, where he was appointed organist of St. Lorenz Church. However, he left the university due to financial difficulties and completed his studies at the Gymnasium Poeticum in Regensburg.

events.title: Employment in Vienna
events.summary: Pachelbel became a deputy organist at the Saint Stephen Cathedral in Vienna, where he spent five years absorbing Italian music and developing his style, influenced by renowned composers of the time.
events.fun_version: In a quirky twist, Pachelbel became a deputy organist at the Saint Stephen Cathedral in Vienna, soaking in Italian music for five years while developing his style influenced by the renowned composers of the time.

events.title: Court Organist in Eisenach
events.summary: In 1677, Pachelbel moved to Eisenach to work as court organist under Kapellmeister Daniel Eberlin. He became a close friend and tutor to members of the Bach family during his time there.
events.fun_version: In 1677, when wigs were fashionable, Pachelbel took a grand leap to Eisenach where he became the court organist under Kapellmeister Daniel Eberlin. He not only became famous for his organ skills but also became a close friend and tutor to the Bach family, offering them advice that probably helped them avoid musical mishaps!

events.title: Organist at Predigerkirche
events.summary: Pachelbel took up the position of organist at Predigerkirche in Erfurt, where he remained for 12 years, built a reputation as a leading organ composer, and composed many chorale preludes for church services.
events.fun_version: Pachelbel landed the gig of organist at Predigerkirche in Erfurt and decided to stick around for 12 long years. He composed organ music as if it was his job—which, funnily enough, it was! He even created many chorale preludes for church services, building a reputation as a leading organ composer.

events.title: First Marriage
events.summary: Pachelbel married Barbara Gabler, the daughter of the Stadt-Major of Erfurt. Unfortunately, both Barbara and their only son died during a plague outbreak in October 1683.
events.fun_version: Pachelbel married Barbara Gabler, the daughter of the Stadt-Major of Erfurt. Unfortunately, during a plague outbreak in October 1683, both Barbara and their only son died.

events.title: Second Marriage
events.summary: Ten months after the death of his first wife, Pachelbel married Judith Drommer. Together, they had five sons and two daughters, with some of his sons following in his musical footsteps.
events.fun_version: After a dramatic ten months filled with widow hood, Pachelbel decided to tie the knot again with Judith Drommer after the passing of his first wife. Together, they produced a soccer team of children—five sons and two daughters! Apparently, some of his sons thought ‘making music’ meant more than just teasing the family cat with a piano solo.

events.title: Employment in Stuttgart
events.summary: Pachelbel became a musician-organist at the Württemberg court in Stuttgart, where he was employed shortly before fleeing due to the French attacks of the War of the Grand Alliance.
events.fun_version: So, picture this: Pachelbel, a soon-to-be-famous musician-organist, lands a gig at the Wüttemberg court in Stuttgart. But just as he starts to hit the high notes, the French attacks during the War of the Grand Alliance made it a musical necessity for him to make a dramatic exit!

events.title: Final Years in Nuremberg
events.summary: After declining offers in Stuttgart and England, Pachelbel returned to Nuremberg in 1695 and lived there until his death. He published important works, including a set of keyboard variations.
events.fun_version: Pachelbel, the musical superstar of the late 1600s, was so picky about his gigs that he turned down offers from Stuttgart and England! He decided to chill in Nuremberg, where he lived until his death in 1695, creating catchy tunes. In between composing and playing, he was also working on the ultimate collection of keyboard variations.

events.title: Death
events.summary: Johann Pachelbel died at the age of 52 and was buried in the St. Rochus Cemetery in Nuremberg. There is some uncertainty about the exact date of his death, but he was buried shortly after.
events.fun_version: Johann Pachelbel kicked the bucket at 52 - maybe his infamous Canon in D finally drove him mad! He was buried shortly after in St. Rochus Cemetery in Nuremberg, where he can still hear the sweet sounds of string instruments.
